Notes: Last large eruption in the Yellowstone National Park area
Part of the Mid-Tertiary ignimbrite flare-up
Largest in the Southern Hemisphere in the Late Quaternary
The largest of the Indian Peak-Caliente Caldera Complex, and includes flows over 13,000 feet thick at the most.
Part of at least 20 large caldera-forming eruptions in the San Juan volcanic field and surrounding area that formed around 26 to 35 Ma
Also includes a 900 cubic km tuff as a second member in the tuff
Existence as a single volcano is controversial. Possibly a volcano chain.[4]
May have helped kill the dinosaurs.
Along with Siberian Traps, may have contributed to the Permian–Triassic extinction event.
Consists of at least 150 individual flows.
Well exposed by Missoula Floods in the Channeled Scablands.
